posts.content: The results of Washington State Teacher of the Year Kim Broomer’s unique classroom environment are impressive. Not only are students learning empathy and belonging—they're also testing above district and state averages on both reading and math.
Thanks to heroic nurses like Agnes Nambozo, Uganda has seen remarkable progress in reducing childhood mortality.
I hope more kids get to learn in a classroom like Kim Broomer’s.

Women’s health has long been underfunded, under-researched, and overlooked. The Gates Foundation is investing $2.5 billion through 2030 to change that—because improving the health outcomes of women is key to greater prosperity and well-being for everyone:
It’s thrilling to see fusion energy getting closer to a breakthrough. Commercial fusion power would be a huge leap in fighting climate change.

Diarrhea was once one of the top killers of children. Today, deaths from diarrhea have dropped by 72% thanks to affordable rotavirus vaccines, organizations like Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, and improved sanitation. But with almost 350,000 children still dying each year, and new threats emerging, the fight is far from over:

As a nurse, Agnes Nambozo knows that vaccines save lives—that's why she’s riding on motorbikes, hiking through mountains, and climbing rickety 1,000-foot ladders to deliver them to families in the most remote parts of Uganda.
Agnes Nambozo climbs 1,000 foot ladders to vaccinate children in remote Ugandan villages.
Agnes climbs 1,000-foot ladders to vaccinate children in remote Ugandan villages. Even after U.S. funding cuts forced her clinic to lose staff, she keeps showing up—because to her, “love is a verb.”
Tuberculosis really is everywhere, once you start looking: https://lnkd.in/g4XZ4kmz

Nuclear power is key to delivering affordable, reliable energy to everyone—in the U.S. and around the world. I always love getting to spend time with the team at TerraPower and seeing the amazing progress they’re making.
The surprising reason I got involved in global health:
Diarrhea used to be one of the biggest killers of children—but now it’s one of the greatest global health success stories.
David is alive today because he was able to access TB treatment. U.S. funding for global health made that possible—for him and millions more.

Tuberculosis has killed more people than any disease in human history. John Green’s Everything Is Tuberculosis explains why it persists—and the reality that, in his words, “the cure is where the disease is not, and the disease is where the cure is not.”
Everything Is Tuberculosis makes one thing clear: this disease isn’t just in the past—it’s in the present, and without action, it’s in our future. https://lnkd.in/g3FE5V9s

I was sorry to learn about the passing of my friend Bill Neukom. Nearly 50 years ago, my dad suggested that I talk to his colleague Bill about Microsoft. That first conversation led to decades of invaluable guidance and partnership. I’m sending my condolences to the entire Neukom family.
Thanks to scientific collaboration, we've made tremendous strides in Alzheimer’s research. Now is the time to spend more money on R&D, not less: https://lnkd.in/gPhR5yDv
The story of the Stetson hat is a reminder: TB has shaped more than health—it’s shaped history: https://lnkd.in/ebUeWUUR

Too many people in the U.S. are working hard but still struggling to make ends meet.

With rapid advancements in technology, especially in artificial intelligence, we have incredible opportunities to help more low-income Americans get on a path to prosperity and better support the frontline workers who serve them.

NextLadder Ventures is an ambitious new organization launched by the Ballmer Group, Stand Together, the Valhalla Foundation, John Overdeck, and the Gates Foundation, with a collective commitment of more than $1 billion to expand economic opportunity for people experiencing poverty across the country.

Everyone deserves the opportunity to achieve their ambitions. We’re excited about what’s possible to help people live more prosperous lives when bold ideas, deep expertise, and remarkable partners come together.

I’ve entered the startup world again…

When your daughter asks if you’d be willing to work a shift in customer service at her startup, the only right answer is yes.

I’ve spent a lot of time thinking about how technology can make systems more efficient, equitable, and accessible. But I’ve learned over the years that the best way to understand how something works, or where it breaks, is to go straight to the people using it.

That’s why I’ll be joining thecustomer experience team for a day this week. Phia is a fashion-tech tool built to make shopping smarter and more sustainable, and it’s the brainchild of my daughterand her co-founder.

They’ve built an app and browser extension that helps people shop smarter by finding the best prices, surfacing secondhand options, and showing lower-impact alternatives across thousands of online retailers.

It’s been inspiring to watch them tackle a massive challenge, rethinking the way we shop, by meeting users where they are.

And now, I’ll be doing the same.

Looking forward to getting back into the startup scene. Hopefully, I won’t break anything (no promises).

📲Download the Phia iOS app for free at

💻Or if you shop on your computer like me, they have a free chrome extension at

Let me know what you think! You never know who’s on the other end of the customer service line…
Vaccines save lives—cutting support for the organizations that deliver them puts millions of children in danger.

Over the past 25 years, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance has helped vaccinate more than a billion children—and prevented more than 19 million deaths from preventable diseases. This life-saving work must continue.
U.S. health aid enables community health workers like Agnes Nambozo, a vaccinator in Uganda, to save lives. Cutting this funding puts millions of people around the world at risk.

I’ve been working in global health for 25 years—as long as I was CEO of Microsoft. At this point, I know as much about improving health in poor countries as I do about software. And I’m certain that just as U.S. health aid saves lives. And when that aid is cut—abruptly and without a plan—lives are lost.
Global health funding is less than 1% of the U.S federal budget—and cutting it will cost over a million lives.
An exciting step toward commercial fusion—and exactly the kind of progress a clean energy future demands.

Keeping vaccines cold is one of the biggest challenges of protecting hard-to-reach communities from deadly diseases. Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance is solving that problem every day: https://lnkd.in/g4K4mVgN
U.S. global health and development aid is estimated to have saved 92 million lives over the past 20 years. We can't afford to let that kind of progress unravel: https://b-gat.es/4kjSUCG
This powerful episode of “This American Life” explores what’s at stake with the dismantling of U.S. global health and development aid.

Warren’s extraordinary philanthropy has helped more kids live to see their fifth birthdays, lifted people out of poverty, and gotten us closer than ever to eradicating diseases like polio. Without him, the progress themade in the last 25 years wouldn't have been possible—and our next 20 years would look a lot less hopeful. He has been my greatest influence, a true model of generosity, and someone I feel incredibly grateful to call a friend.

Helping countries become self-reliant is how we reduce global poverty, strengthen public health, and create geopolitical stability. USAID has played a key role in that work for decades. Dismantling it puts all this progress—and millions of lives—at risk.

Because countries around the world are cutting their health aid budgets, there’s never been a point in the past 25 years when more lives hung in the balance. Despite the current headwinds, I’m not giving into pessimism. In fact, over the next few decades, the progress we could make is enormous if we keep up our momentum. So I’ll keep making the case everywhere I go: There is no better investment we could make in our future than in global health programs that save kids’ lives.

In all likelihood, 2025 will be the first year since the turn of the century when the number of children dying will go up instead of down. The most critical step we can take to change course is to fund Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance.

In the last 25 years, Gavi has helped over a billion kids live better, healthier lives. Pulling the organization’s funding would have devastating consequences: more sick kids who fall behind in school, more overcrowded hospital wards, and eventually more grieving parents. I’m urging Congress to rethink this decision, fund Gavi, and help save millions more lives.
Health aid works.
We’re already seeing the tragic impact of reductions in aid, and we know the number of deaths will continue to rise. Here’s the proof I’m showing Congress: https://lnkd.in/gQYNKzGF

Child mortality has decreased over the past 25 years—in large part thanks to vaccines. But now, as funding for health and immunization programs is being cut around the world, the number of kids who die from preventable causes each year will rise. This is a tragedy—and the case for vaccines has never been more clear.

That’s why theis committing $1.6 billion over the next five years to support.

Gavi is easily the smartest investment the world can make to save kids’ lives.

We hope others will join us—because the cost of falling short will be measured in lives lost. Let’s recommit to immunization for every child and
.
It was a lot of fun to reflect on the super impressive work that has been accomplished over the years. Can't wait to do it again!

With the first blood-based diagnostic tests now available—and new treatments that may prove even more effective when used early—we’re on the cusp of turning the tide against Alzheimer’s. I wish these breakthroughs had come in time for my dad to benefit from them, but I’m hopeful they’ll change the odds for millions of other families.
With all the new tools in the pipeline for Alzheimer’s drug development, I believe we’re on the cusp of a big breakthrough: http://gatesnot.es/4e9CU4M
Personal History captures how Katharine Graham became one of the most courageous figures in journalism—and why, to this day, I and so many others still look up to and learn from her.

In 1997, Nick Kristof wrote a New York Times column about the huge number of children in poor countries who were dying from diarrhea. At the time, I wasn’t sure how I wanted to give my wealth back to society, but this piece inspired me. I faxed it to my dad with a note: “Maybe we can do something about this.” That was the beginning of the Gates Foundation, and of my friendship with Nick.

We know what it takes to eradicate deadly diseases, because we've done it before. But we won’t succeed and save lives without global cooperation and a commitment to reach everyone, everywhere. Cutting global health aid isn’t just shortsighted—it’s dangerous.

By accelerating the Gates Foundation’s giving over the next 20 years, my hope is that we will put the world on a path to ending preventable deaths of moms and babies, eradicate deadly infectious diseases, and lift millions of people out of poverty.

Every year, 2.3 million newborns don’t survive their first 28 days. But simple, low-cost interventions that identify risks early, improve prenatal care, and help mothers survive delivery can give more of these babies a fighting chance.

Writing Source Code made me think hard about what makes a great memoir, so I turned to my favorites. From Kay Graham’s journey as a trailblazer in journalism to Trevor Noah’s reflections on feeling out of place growing up, here are some of the memoirs that inspire me.

For millions of babies born too soon, survival depends on access to basic care. I’ve seen how innovations like synthetic surfactant and portable ultrasounds can turn fear into celebration. Now we need to get them to the places that need them most.

This is an incredible step forward for Alzheimer’s diagnostics. When it comes to this disease, early detection makes all the difference. For patients and their families, these tests mean more time and more options—and helping advance work like this is why the’s Diagnostics Accelerator exists.
For millions of premature babies, the difference between life and death depends on access to life-saving care. We can change the trajectory of neonatal deaths everywhere with this simple nebulizer.
